author:
Jimmy Durkin

jdurkin@bayareanewsgroup.com
title: Broncos beat Raiders 16-10
text:
Raiders news on Facebook OAKLAND -- Derek Carr's worst pass of the season came at a bad time as he threw a fourth quarter pick-six and the Raiders lost to the Denver Broncos 16-10 on Sunday at O.co Coliseum. 
Sebastian Janikowski missed two field goals on the day he set the Raiders franchise record for games played at 241, and the Broncos (5-0) won for the second time this season without scoring an offensive touchdown. 
The Raiders (2-3) were within Janikowski's normal field goal range at the Broncos' 31 when Carr sailed a pass behind Seth Roberts that Chris Harris Jr. picked off and took 74 yards for a touchdown with 6:53 to play. 
That didn't end the game, but it was a major gut punch after the Raiders spent most of the afternoon going toe-to-toe with the AFC West leaders. Oakland Raiders' Latavius Murray (28) runs against Denver Broncos' Danny Trevathan (59) in the first quarter of their NFL game at O.co Coliseum in Oakland, Calif, on Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015. ( Nhat V. Meyer ) 
The Raiders turned it over on downs on their ensuing possession, watching a 13-play drive end when a fourth-and-19 screen pass to Marcel Reece netted just 4 yards. 
Oakland pulled within 16-10 with 1:40 to go when Janikowski made a 50-yard field goal. The Raiders sent him out there for the kick right after getting a 48-yard pass interference call on Denver. 
The game's fate was left up to the onside kick, and Demaryius Thomas easily fielded the kick to secure the Broncos' win. 
The Raiders lost despite keeping Peyton Manning out of the end zone and intercepting him twice, both by veteran safety Charles Woodson. They were Woodson's first interceptions in nine career meetings with Manning and give him 64 for his career, tying him with Ed Reed for sixth on the all-time list. Advertisement 
The Raiders moved the ball pretty well early in the game, but a holding penalty stalled their first drive, and Janikowski's low kick on a 38-yard field goal was blocked to conclude the second possession. 
Denver grabbed the lead right after Janikowski's miss, going deep for a 45-yard pass to Emmanuel Sanders on the next play to help set up a Brandon McManus 25-yard field goal. 
Oakland pulled ahead with the only touchdown drive of the game. 
Carr converted a third-and-3 with a laser of a pass to Amari Cooper on a slant for 21 yards. Two plays later, with the offensive line giving Carr loads of time, he hit a wide open Clive Walford for a 33-yard gain that reached the Denver 3. On second-and-goal, the Raiders used play action to perfection and Carr flipped a 3-yard touchdown pass to fullback Reece. 
The Broncos threatened to take the lead late in the first half, navigating their way to the Oakland 9. A 41-yard pass from Manning to Bennie Fowler was the big play in the sequence. 
But on third-and-5 from the 9, Malcolm Smith pressured Manning with a blitz and rookie linebacker Neiron Ball had good coverage on tight end Owen Daniels, who never tracked the ball, and it was intercepted in the end zone by Woodson. Denver Broncos' Jordan Norwood (11) runs after a catch against Oakland Raiders' TJ Carrie (38) in the first quarter of their NFL game at O.co Coliseum in Oakland, Calif, on Sunday, Oct. 11, 2015. ( Nhat V. Meyer ) 
Denver's Von Miller made a big defensive play of his own early in the third quarter when he blew past Austin Howard and sacked Carr, forcing a fumble that he recovered. But the Raiders defense steadied and limited the Broncos to a 20-yard field goal by McManus. The Broncos took the lead a possession later with a 52-yard field goal by McManus. 
The Raiders seized some momentum late in the third quarter when Woodson picked off Manning again. Manning tried to target Thomas, and Woodson flew over the top to make the leaping interception. 
Oakland drove to within field goal range, but Janikowski missed again, this time going wide left on a 40-yard kick. For more on the Raiders, visit the Inside the Oakland Raiders blog at ibabuzz.com/oaklandraiders . Follow Jimmy Durkin on Twitter at Twitter.com/Jimmy_Durkin .
